an10.44:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kusinārāyaṃ viharati baliharaṇe vanasaṇḍe.
an10.44:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kusinārā, in the Forest of Offerings.

an10.44:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an10.44:2.1.pli: “Codakena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā paraṃ codetukāmena pañca dhamme ajjhattaṃ paccavekkhitvā pañca dhamme ajjhattaṃ upaṭṭhāpetvā paro codetabbo.
an10.44:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should first check five things in themselves and establish five things in themselves.

an10.44:2.2.eng: What five things should they check in themselves?

an10.44:2.3.pli: Codakena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā paraṃ codetukāmena evaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ:
an10.44:2.3.eng: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:

an10.44:2.4.pli: ‘parisuddhakāyasamācāro nu khomhi, parisuddhenamhi kāyasamācārena samannāgato acchiddena appaṭimaṃsena.
an10.44:2.4.eng: ‘Is my bodily behavior pure? Do I have pure bodily behavior that is impeccable and irreproachable?

an10.44:2.5.pli: Saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no’ti?
an10.44:2.5.eng: Is this thing found in me or not?’

an10.44:2.6.pli: No ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu parisuddhakāyasamācāro hoti parisuddhena kāyasamācārena samannāgato acchiddena appaṭimaṃsena, tassa bhavanti vattāro:
an10.44:2.6.eng: If it’s not, there will be people who say:

an10.44:2.7.pli: ‘iṅgha tāva āyasmā kāyikaṃ sikkhassū’ti, itissa bhavanti vattāro.
an10.44:2.7.eng: ‘Come on, venerable, train your own bodily behavior first.’

an10.44:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, codakena bhikkhunā paraṃ codetukāmena evaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ:
an10.44:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:

an10.44:3.2.pli: ‘parisuddhavacīsamācāro nu khomhi, parisuddhenamhi vacīsamācārena samannāgato acchiddena appaṭimaṃsena.
an10.44:3.2.eng: ‘Is my verbal behavior pure? Do I have pure verbal behavior that is impeccable and irreproachable?

an10.44:3.3.pli: Saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no’ti?
an10.44:3.3.eng: Is this thing found in me or not?’

an10.44:3.4.pli: No ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu parisuddhavacīsamācāro hoti parisuddhena vacīsamācārena samannāgato acchiddena appaṭimaṃsena, tassa bhavanti vattāro:
an10.44:3.4.eng: If it’s not, there will be people who say:

an10.44:3.5.pli: ‘iṅgha tāva āyasmā vācasikaṃ sikkhassū’ti, itissa bhavanti vattāro.
an10.44:3.5.eng: ‘Come on, venerable, train your own verbal behavior first.’

an10.44:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, codakena bhikkhunā paraṃ codetukāmena evaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ:
an10.44:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:

an10.44:4.2.pli: ‘mettaṃ nu kho me cittaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ sabrahmacārīsu anāghātaṃ.
an10.44:4.2.eng: ‘Is my heart established in love for my spiritual companions, without resentment?

an10.44:4.3.pli: Saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no’ti?
an10.44:4.3.eng: Is this thing found in me or not?’

an10.44:4.4.pli: No ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno mettaṃ cittaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu anāghātaṃ, tassa bhavanti vattāro:
an10.44:4.4.eng: If it’s not, there will be people who say:

an10.44:4.5.pli: ‘iṅgha tāva āyasmā sabrahmacārīsu mettaṃ cittaṃ upaṭṭhāpehī’ti, itissa bhavanti vattāro.
an10.44:4.5.eng: ‘Come on, venerable, establish your heart in love for your spiritual companions first.’

an10.44:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, codakena bhikkhunā paraṃ codetukāmena evaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ:
an10.44:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:

an10.44:5.2.pli: ‘bahussuto nu khomhi sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpā me dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
an10.44:5.2.eng: ‘Am I very learned, remembering and keeping what I’ve learned? These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. Am I very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically?

an10.44:5.3.pli: Saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no’ti?
an10.44:5.3.eng: Is this thing found in me or not?’

an10.44:5.4.pli: No ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo, ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā, tassa bhavanti vattāro:
an10.44:5.4.eng: If it’s not, there will be people who say:

an10.44:5.5.pli: ‘iṅgha tāva āyasmā āgamaṃ pariyāpuṇassū’ti, itissa bhavanti vattāro.
an10.44:5.5.eng: ‘Come on, venerable, memorize the scriptures first.’

an10.44:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, codakena bhikkhunā paraṃ codetukāmena evaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ:
an10.44:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant who wants to accuse another should check this:

an10.44:6.2.pli: ‘ubhayāni kho pana me pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti suvibhattāni suppavattīni suvinicchitāni suttaso anubyañjanaso.
an10.44:6.2.eng: ‘Have both monastic codes been passed down to me in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, and well evaluated in both the rules and accompanying material?

an10.44:6.3.pli: Saṃvijjati nu kho me eso dhammo udāhu no’ti?
an10.44:6.3.eng: Is this thing found in me or not?’

an10.44:6.4.pli: No ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ubhayāni pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti suvibhattāni suppavattīni suvinicchitāni suttaso anubyañjanaso, ‘idaṃ panāyasmā, kattha vuttaṃ bhagavatā’ti, iti puṭṭho na sampāyissati.
an10.44:6.4.eng: If it’s not, and if they are unable to respond when asked “Venerable, where was this spoken by the Buddha?” there will be people who say:

an10.44:6.6.pli: ‘iṅgha tāva āyasmā vinayaṃ sikkhassū’ti, itissa bhavanti vattāro.
an10.44:6.6.eng: ‘Come on, venerable, train in the monastic code first.’

an10.44:6.7.eng: These are the five things they should check in themselves.

an10.44:7.1.eng: What five things should they establish in themselves?

an10.44:7.2.eng: ‘I will speak at the right time, not at the wrong time.

an10.44:7.3.eng: I will speak truthfully, not falsely.

an10.44:7.4.eng: I will speak gently, not harshly.

an10.44:7.5.eng: I will speak beneficially, not harmfully.

an10.44:7.6.eng: I will speak lovingly, not from secret hate.’

an10.44:7.7.eng: These are the five things they should establish in themselves.

an10.44:7.8.pli: Codakena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā paraṃ codetukāmena ime pañca dhamme ajjhattaṃ paccavekkhitvā ime pañca dhamme ajjhattaṃ upaṭṭhāpetvā paro codetabbo”ti.
an10.44:7.8.eng: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should first check these five things in themselves and establish these five things in themselves.”

an10.45:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are ten drawbacks to entering a royal compound.

an10.45:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rājā mahesiyā saddhiṃ nisinno hoti.
an10.45:1.3.eng: Firstly, a king is sitting with his chief queen

an10.45:1.5.pli: Mahesī vā bhikkhuṃ disvā sitaṃ pātukaroti, bhikkhu vā mahesiṃ disvā sitaṃ pātukaroti.
an10.45:1.5.eng: When the queen sees the monk she smiles, or when the monk sees the queen he smiles.

an10.45:1.7.eng: ‘They’ve done it for sure, or they will do it.’

an10.45:1.8.eng: This is the first drawback of entering a royal compound.

an10.45:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, rājā bahukicco bahukaraṇīyo aññataraṃ itthiṃ gantvā na sarati:
an10.45:2.1.eng: Furthermore, a king has many duties, and much to do. He has sex with one of the women but doesn’t remember.

an10.45:2.4.pli: ‘na kho idha añño koci pavisati, aññatra pabbajitena.
an10.45:2.4.eng: ‘No-one else has entered here, except for that monk.

an10.45:2.5.eng: Could this be the monk’s doing?’

an10.45:2.6.eng: This is the second drawback of entering a royal compound.

an10.45:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, rañño antepure aññataraṃ ratanaṃ nassati.
an10.45:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a gem is lost somewhere in the royal compound.

an10.45:3.3.pli: ‘na kho idha añño koci pavisati, aññatra pabbajitena.
an10.45:3.3.eng: ‘No-one else has entered here, except for that monk.

an10.45:3.4.eng: Could this be the monk’s doing?’

an10.45:3.5.eng: This is the third drawback of entering a royal compound.

an10.45:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, rañño antepure abbhantarā guyhamantā bahiddhā sambhedaṃ gacchanti.
an10.45:4.1.eng: Furthermore, secret deliberations in the royal compound are leaked outside.

an10.45:4.3.pli: ‘na kho idha añño koci pavisati, aññatra pabbajitena.
an10.45:4.3.eng: ‘No-one else has entered here, except for that monk.

an10.45:4.4.eng: Could this be the monk’s doing?’

an10.45:4.5.eng: This is the fourth drawback of entering a royal compound.

an10.45:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, rañño antepure pitā vā puttaṃ pattheti putto vā pitaraṃ pattheti.
an10.45:5.1.eng: Furthermore, in a royal compound, a father longs for their son, or a son longs for his father.

an10.45:5.3.pli: ‘na kho idha añño koci pavisati, aññatra pabbajitena.
an10.45:5.3.eng: ‘No-one else has entered here, except for that monk.

an10.45:5.4.eng: Could this be the monk’s doing?’

an10.45:5.5.eng: This is the fifth drawback of entering a royal compound.

an10.45:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, rājā nīcaṭṭhāniyaṃ ucce ṭhāne ṭhapeti.
an10.45:6.1.eng: Furthermore, the king promotes someone to a higher position.

an10.45:6.2.pli: Yesaṃ taṃ amanāpaṃ tesaṃ evaṃ hoti:
an10.45:6.2.eng: Those who are upset by this think:

an10.45:6.3.eng: ‘The king is close to that monk.

an10.45:6.4.eng: Could this be the monk’s doing?’

an10.45:6.5.eng: This is the sixth drawback of entering a royal compound.

an10.45:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, rājā uccaṭṭhāniyaṃ nīce ṭhāne ṭhapeti.
an10.45:7.1.eng: Furthermore, the king demotes someone to a lower position.

an10.45:7.2.pli: Yesaṃ taṃ amanāpaṃ tesaṃ evaṃ hoti:
an10.45:7.2.eng: Those who are upset by this think:

an10.45:7.3.eng: ‘The king is close to that monk.

an10.45:7.4.eng: Could this be the monk’s doing?’

an10.45:7.5.eng: This is the seventh drawback of entering a royal compound.

an10.45:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, rājā akāle senaṃ uyyojeti.
an10.45:8.1.eng: Furthermore, the king dispatches the army at the wrong time.

an10.45:8.2.pli: Yesaṃ taṃ amanāpaṃ tesaṃ evaṃ hoti:
an10.45:8.2.eng: Those who are upset by this think:

an10.45:8.3.eng: ‘The king is close to that monk.

an10.45:8.4.eng: Could this be the monk’s doing?’

an10.45:8.5.eng: This is the eighth drawback of entering a royal compound.

an10.45:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, rājā kāle senaṃ uyyojetvā antarāmaggato nivattāpeti.
an10.45:9.1.eng: Furthermore, the king dispatches the army at the right time, but orders it to turn back while still on the road.

an10.45:9.2.pli: Yesaṃ taṃ amanāpaṃ tesaṃ evaṃ hoti:
an10.45:9.2.eng: Those who are upset by this think:

an10.45:9.3.eng: ‘The king is close to that monk.

an10.45:9.4.eng: Could this be the monk’s doing?’

an10.45:9.5.eng: This is the ninth drawback of entering a royal compound.

an10.45:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, rañño antepuraṃ hatthisammaddaṃ assasammaddaṃ rathasammaddaṃ rajanīyāni rūpasaddagandharasaphoṭṭhabbāni, yāni na pabbajitassa sāruppāni.
an10.45:10.1.eng: Furthermore, in the royal compound there is a trampling of elephants, horses, and chariots, as well as arousing sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches that do not befit a monk.

an10.45:10.2.eng: This is the tenth drawback of entering a royal compound.

an10.45:10.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dasa ādīnavā rājantepurappavesane”ti.
an10.45:10.3.eng: These are the ten drawbacks of entering a royal compound.”

an10.46:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
an10.46:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

an10.46:1.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā sakkā upāsakā tadahuposathe yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho sakke upāsake bhagavā etadavoca:
an10.46:1.2.eng: Then on the sabbath several Sakyan lay followers went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:

an10.46:1.3.pli: “api nu tumhe, sakkā, aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasathā”ti?
an10.46:1.3.eng: “Sakyans, do you observe the sabbath with its eight factors?”

an10.46:1.4.pli: “Appekadā mayaṃ, bhante, aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasāma, appekadā na upavasāmā”ti.
an10.46:1.4.eng: “Sir, sometimes we do, sometimes we don’t.”

an10.46:1.5.pli: “Tesaṃ vo, sakkā, alābhā tesaṃ dulladdhaṃ, ye tumhe evaṃ sokasabhaye jīvite maraṇasabhaye jīvite appekadā aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasatha, appekadā na upavasatha.
an10.46:1.5.eng: “That’s your loss, Sakyans, it’s your misfortune. In this life with its fear of sorrow and death, you sometimes keep the sabbath and you sometimes don’t.

an10.46:2.2.pli: idha puriso yena kenaci kammaṭṭhānena anāpajja akusalaṃ divasaṃ aḍḍhakahāpaṇaṃ nibbiseyya.
an10.46:2.2.eng: Take a man who earns half a dollar for an honest day’s work.

an10.46:2.3.eng: Is this enough to call him a deft and industrious man?”

an10.46:3.2.pli: idha puriso yena kenaci kammaṭṭhānena anāpajja akusalaṃ divasaṃ kahāpaṇaṃ nibbiseyya.
an10.46:3.2.eng: Take a man who earns a dollar for an honest day’s work.

an10.46:3.3.eng: Is this enough to call him a deft and industrious man?”

an10.46:4.2.pli: idha puriso yena kenaci kammaṭṭhānena anāpajja akusalaṃ divasaṃ dve kahāpaṇe nibbiseyya …
an10.46:4.2.eng: Take a man who, for an honest day’s work, earns two dollars …

an10.46:4.16.eng: Is this enough to call him a deft and industrious man?”

an10.46:5.2.pli: api nu so puriso divase divase kahāpaṇasataṃ kahāpaṇasahassaṃ nibbisamāno laddhaṃ laddhaṃ nikkhipanto vassasatāyuko vassasatajīvī mahantaṃ bhogakkhandhaṃ adhigaccheyyā”ti?
an10.46:5.2.eng: Suppose that man earned a hundred or a thousand dollars every day and saved it all up. If he lived for a hundred years, would he not accumulate a large mass of wealth?”

an10.46:6.2.pli: api nu so puriso bhogahetu bhoganidānaṃ bhogādhikaraṇaṃ ekaṃ vā rattiṃ ekaṃ vā divasaṃ upaḍḍhaṃ vā rattiṃ upaḍḍhaṃ vā divasaṃ ekantasukhappaṭisaṃvedī vihareyyā”ti?
an10.46:6.2.eng: Would that man, on account of that wealth, experience perfect happiness for a single day or night, or even half a day or night?”

an10.46:6.5.pli: “Kāmā hi, bhante, aniccā tucchā musā mosadhammā”ti.
an10.46:6.5.eng: “Because sensual pleasures, sir, are impermanent, hollow, false, and deceptive.”

an10.46:7.1.pli: “Idha pana vo, sakkā, mama sāvako dasa vassāni appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto yathā mayānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā paṭipajjamāno satampi vassāni satampi vassasatāni satampi vassasahassāni ekantasukhappaṭisaṃvedī vihareyya.
an10.46:7.1.eng: “But take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute for ten years, practicing in line with my instructions. They can experience perfect happiness for a hundred years, ten thousand years, or a hundred thousand years.

an10.46:7.2.pli: So ca khvassa sakadāgāmī vā anāgāmī vā apaṇṇakaṃ vā sotāpanno.
an10.46:7.2.eng: And they could become a once-returner or a non-returner, or unfailingly a stream-enterer.

an10.46:8.1.eng: take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute for nine years …

an10.46:8.9.pli: ekaṃ vassaṃ appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto yathā mayānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā paṭipajjamāno satampi vassāni satampi vassasatāni satampi vassasahassāni ekantasukhappaṭisaṃvedī vihareyya, so ca khvassa sakadāgāmī vā anāgāmī vā apaṇṇakaṃ vā sotāpanno.

an10.46:9.1.pli: Idha mama sāvako dasa māse appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto yathā mayānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā paṭipajjamāno satampi vassāni satampi vassasatāni satampi vassasahassāni ekantasukhappaṭisaṃvedī vihareyya, so ca khvassa sakadāgāmī vā anāgāmī vā apaṇṇakaṃ vā sotāpanno.

an10.46:10.10.pli: aḍḍhamāsaṃ appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto yathā mayānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā paṭipajjamāno satampi vassāni satampi vassasatāni satampi vassasahassāni ekantasukhappaṭisaṃvedī vihareyya, so ca khvassa sakadāgāmī vā anāgāmī vā apaṇṇakaṃ vā sotāpanno.

an10.46:11.1.pli: Idha mama sāvako dasa rattindive appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto yathā mayānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā paṭipajjamāno satampi vassāni satampi vassasatāni satampi vassasahassāni ekantasukhappaṭisaṃvedī vihareyya, so ca khvassa sakadāgāmī vā anāgāmī vā apaṇṇakaṃ vā sotāpanno.

an10.46:12.9.pli: ekaṃ rattindivaṃ appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto yathā mayānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā paṭipajjamāno satampi vassāni satampi vassasatāni satampi vassasahassāni ekantasukhappaṭisaṃvedī vihareyya, so ca khvassa sakadāgāmī vā anāgāmī vā apaṇṇakaṃ vā sotāpanno.
an10.46:12.9.eng: Let alone two days, take one of my disciples who lives diligent, keen, and resolute for one day, practicing in line with my instructions. They can experience perfect happiness for a hundred years, ten thousand years, or a hundred thousand years. And they could become a once-returner or a non-returner, or unfailingly a stream-enterer.

an10.46:12.10.pli: Tesaṃ vo, sakkā, alābhā tesaṃ dulladdhaṃ, ye tumhe evaṃ sokasabhaye jīvite maraṇasabhaye jīvite appekadā aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasatha, appekadā na upavasathā”ti.
an10.46:12.10.eng: It’s your loss, Sakyans, it’s your misfortune. In this life with its fear of sorrow and death, you sometimes keep the sabbath and you sometimes don’t.”

an10.46:12.11.pli: “Ete mayaṃ, bhante, ajjatagge aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasissāmā”ti.
an10.46:12.11.eng: “Well, sir, from this day forth we will observe the sabbath with its eight factors.”

an10.47:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
an10.47:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

an10.47:1.2.pli: Atha kho mahāli licchavi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho mahāli licchavi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an10.47:1.2.eng: Then Mahāli the Licchavi went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an10.47:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā”ti?
an10.47:1.3.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason for doing bad deeds, for performing bad deeds?”

an10.47:1.4.pli: “Lobho kho, mahāli, hetu, lobho paccayo pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā.
an10.47:1.4.eng: “Greed is a cause, Mahāli, greed is a reason for doing bad deeds, for performing bad deeds.

an10.47:1.5.pli: Doso kho, mahāli, hetu, doso paccayo pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā.
an10.47:1.5.eng: Hate is a cause of bad deeds …

an10.47:1.6.pli: Moho kho, mahāli, hetu, moho paccayo pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā.
an10.47:1.6.eng: Delusion is a cause of bad deeds …

an10.47:1.7.pli: Ayoniso manasikāro kho, mahāli, hetu, ayoniso manasikāro paccayo pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā.
an10.47:1.7.eng: Irrational application of mind gives rise to bad deeds …

an10.47:1.8.pli: Micchāpaṇihitaṃ kho, mahāli, cittaṃ hetu, micchāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ paccayo pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyāti.
an10.47:1.8.eng: A wrongly directed mind is a cause of bad deeds …

an10.47:1.9.pli: Ayaṃ kho, mahāli, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā”ti.
an10.47:1.9.eng: This is the cause, Mahāli, this is the reason for doing bad deeds, for performing bad deeds.”

an10.47:2.1.pli: “Ko pana, bhante, hetu ko paccayo kalyāṇassa kammassa kiriyāya kalyāṇassa kammassa pavattiyā”ti?
an10.47:2.1.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason for doing good deeds, for performing good deeds?”

an10.47:2.2.pli: “Alobho kho, mahāli, hetu, alobho paccayo kalyāṇassa kammassa kiriyāya kalyāṇassa kammassa pavattiyā.
an10.47:2.2.eng: “Contentment is a cause, Mahāli, contentment is a reason for doing good deeds, for performing good deeds.

an10.47:2.3.pli: Adoso kho, mahāli, hetu, adoso paccayo kalyāṇassa kammassa kiriyāya kalyāṇassa kammassa pavattiyā.
an10.47:2.3.eng: Love is a cause of good deeds …

an10.47:2.4.pli: Amoho kho, mahāli, hetu, amoho paccayo kalyāṇassa kammassa kiriyāya kalyāṇassa kammassa pavattiyā.
an10.47:2.4.eng: Understanding is a cause of good deeds …

an10.47:2.5.pli: Yoniso manasikāro kho, mahāli, hetu, yoniso manasikāro paccayo kalyāṇassa kammassa kiriyāya kalyāṇassa kammassa pavattiyā.
an10.47:2.5.eng: Rational application of mind gives rise to good deeds …

an10.47:2.6.pli: Sammāpaṇihitaṃ kho, mahāli, cittaṃ hetu, sammāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ paccayo kalyāṇassa kammassa kiriyāya kalyāṇassa kammassa pavattiyā.
an10.47:2.6.eng: A rightly directed mind is a cause of good deeds …

an10.47:2.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho, mahāli, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo kalyāṇassa kammassa kiriyāya kalyāṇassa kammassa pavattiyā.
an10.47:2.7.eng: This is the cause, Mahāli, this is the reason for doing good deeds, for performing good deeds.

an10.47:2.8.pli: Ime ca, mahāli, dasa dhammā loke na saṃvijjeyyuṃ, nayidha paññāyetha adhammacariyāvisamacariyāti vā dhammacariyāsamacariyāti vā.
an10.47:2.8.eng: If these ten things were not found in the world, we wouldn’t see either unprincipled and immoral conduct, or principled and moral conduct.

an10.47:2.9.pli: Yasmā ca kho, mahāli, ime dasa dhammā loke saṃvijjanti, tasmā paññāyati adhammacariyāvisamacariyāti vā dhammacariyāsamacariyāti vā”ti.
an10.47:2.9.eng: But since these ten things are found in the world, we see both unprincipled and immoral conduct, and principled and moral conduct.”

an10.48:0.3.eng: Ten Regular Reflections for a Renunciate

an10.48:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, one who has gone forth should often review these ten things.

an10.48:2.1.eng: One who has gone forth should often review this: ‘I have secured freedom from class.’

an10.48:3.1.eng: ‘My livelihood is tied up with others.’

an10.48:4.1.pli: ‘Añño me ākappo karaṇīyo’ti pabbajitena abhiṇhaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ.

an10.48:5.1.pli: ‘Kacci nu kho me attā sīlato na upavadatī’ti pabbajitena abhiṇhaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ.
an10.48:5.1.eng: ‘I hope there’s no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct?’

an10.48:6.1.pli: ‘Kacci nu kho maṃ anuvicca viññū sabrahmacārī sīlato na upavadantī’ti pabbajitena abhiṇhaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ.
an10.48:6.1.eng: ‘I hope that, after examination, sensible spiritual companions don’t reproach any aspect of my ethics?’

an10.48:7.1.pli: ‘Sabbehi me piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo’ti pabbajitena abhiṇhaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ.
an10.48:7.1.eng: ‘I must be parted and separated from all I hold dear and beloved.’

an10.48:8.1.eng: ‘I am the owner of my deeds and heir to my deeds. Deeds are my womb, my relative, and my refuge.

an10.48:9.1.pli: yaṃ kammaṃ karissāmi kalyāṇaṃ vā pāpakaṃ vā tassa dāyādo bhavissāmī’ti pabbajitena abhiṇhaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ.
an10.48:9.1.eng: I shall be the heir of whatever deeds I do, whether good or bad.’

an10.48:10.1.pli: ‘Kathaṃbhūtassa me rattindivā vītivattantī’ti pabbajitena abhiṇhaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ.
an10.48:10.1.eng: ‘As the days and nights pass by, what sort of person am I becoming?’

an10.48:11.1.pli: ‘Kacci nu kho ahaṃ suññāgāre abhiramāmī’ti pabbajitena abhiṇhaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ.
an10.48:11.1.eng: ‘Do I love to stay in empty huts?’

an10.48:12.1.pli: ‘Atthi nu kho me uttari manussadhammo alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato, yenāhaṃ pacchime kāle sabrahmacārīhi puṭṭho na maṅku bhavissāmī’ti pabbajitena abhiṇhaṃ paccavekkhitabbaṃ.
an10.48:12.1.eng: ‘Do I have any superhuman distinctions in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, so that when my spiritual companions question me on my deathbed I will not be embarrassed?’

an10.48:13.1.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dasa dhammā pabbajitena abhiṇhaṃ paccavekkhitabbā”ti.
an10.48:13.1.eng: One who has gone forth should often review these ten things.”

an10.49:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these ten things exist because of the body.

an10.49:1.3.pli: Sītaṃ, uṇhaṃ, jighacchā, pipāsā, uccāro, passāvo, kāyasaṃvaro, vacīsaṃvaro, ājīvasaṃvaro, ponobhaviko bhavasaṅkhāro—
an10.49:1.3.eng: Cold, heat, hunger, thirst, feces, urine, restraint of body, speech, and livelihood, and the will to live that leads to future lives.

an10.49:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, dasa dhammā sarīraṭṭhā”ti.
an10.49:1.4.eng: These ten things exist because of the body.”

an10.5:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā ānando bhikkhū āmantesi …pe…
an10.5:1.1.eng: There Venerable Ānanda addressed the mendicants …

an10.5:1.2.eng: “Reverends, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for having no regrets.

an10.5:1.3.pli: avippaṭisāre asati avippaṭisāravipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti pāmojjaṃ;
an10.5:1.3.eng: When there are regrets, one who has regrets has destroyed a vital condition for joy.

an10.5:1.4.pli: pāmojje asati pāmojjavipannassa hatūpanisā hoti pīti;
an10.5:1.4.eng: When there is no joy, one who lacks joy has destroyed a vital condition for rapture.

an10.5:1.5.pli: pītiyā asati pītivipannassa hatūpanisā hoti passaddhi;
an10.5:1.5.eng: When there is no rapture, one who lacks rapture has destroyed a vital condition for tranquility.

an10.5:1.6.pli: passaddhiyā asati passaddhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti sukhaṃ;
an10.5:1.6.eng: When there is no tranquility, one who lacks tranquility has destroyed a vital condition for bliss.

an10.5:1.7.pli: sukhe asati sukhavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti sammāsamādhi;
an10.5:1.7.eng: When there is no bliss, one who lacks bliss has destroyed a vital condition for right immersion.

an10.5:1.8.pli: sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an10.5:1.8.eng: When there is no right immersion, one who lacks right immersion has destroyed a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an10.5:1.9.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane asati yathābhūtañāṇadassanavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an10.5:1.9.eng: When there is no true knowledge and vision, one who lacks true knowledge and vision has destroyed a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an10.5:1.10.pli: nibbidāvirāge asati nibbidāvirāgavipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an10.5:1.10.eng: When there is no disillusionment and dispassion, one who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an10.5:1.11.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, rukkho sākhāpalāsavipanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi na pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi … pheggupi … sāropi na pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an10.5:1.11.eng: Suppose there was a tree that lacked branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would not grow to fullness.

an10.5:1.12.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, dussīlassa sīlavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti avippaṭisāro;
an10.5:1.12.eng: In the same way, an unethical person, who lacks ethics, has destroyed a vital condition for having no regrets.

an10.5:1.13.eng: When there are regrets, one who has regrets has destroyed a vital condition for joy. …

an10.5:1.14.eng: One who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an10.5:2.1.pli: Sīlavato, āvuso, sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti avippaṭisāro;
an10.5:2.1.eng: An ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for not having regrets.

an10.5:2.2.pli: avippaṭisāre sati avippaṭisārasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti pāmojjaṃ;
an10.5:2.2.eng: When there are no regrets, one who has no regrets has fulfilled a vital condition for joy.

an10.5:2.3.pli: pāmojje sati pāmojjasampannassa upanisasampannā hoti pīti;
an10.5:2.3.eng: When there is joy, one who has fulfilled joy has fulfilled a vital condition for rapture.

an10.5:2.4.pli: pītiyā sati pītisampannassa upanisasampannā hoti passaddhi;
an10.5:2.4.eng: When there is rapture, one who has fulfilled rapture has fulfilled a vital condition for tranquility.

an10.5:2.5.pli: passaddhiyā sati passaddhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti sukhaṃ;
an10.5:2.5.eng: When there is tranquility, one who has fulfilled tranquility has fulfilled a vital condition for bliss.

an10.5:2.6.pli: sukhe sati sukhasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti sammāsamādhi;
an10.5:2.6.eng: When there is bliss, one who has fulfilled bliss has fulfilled a vital condition for right immersion.

an10.5:2.7.pli: sammāsamādhimhi sati sammāsamādhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an10.5:2.7.eng: When there is right immersion, one who has fulfilled right immersion has fulfilled a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an10.5:2.8.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane sati yathābhūtañāṇadassanasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an10.5:2.8.eng: When there is true knowledge and vision, one who has fulfilled true knowledge and vision has fulfilled a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an10.5:2.9.pli: nibbidāvirāge sati nibbidāvirāgasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an10.5:2.9.eng: When there is disillusionment and dispassion, one who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an10.5:2.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, rukkho sākhāpalāsasampanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi … pheggupi … sāropi pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an10.5:2.10.eng: Suppose there was a tree that was complete with branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would grow to fullness.

an10.5:2.11.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, āvuso, sīlavato sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti avippaṭisāro;
an10.5:2.11.eng: In the same way, an ethical person, who has fulfilled ethics, has fulfilled a vital condition for not having regrets.

an10.5:2.12.eng: When there are no regrets, one who has no regrets has fulfilled a vital condition for joy. …

an10.5:2.13.eng: One who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.”
